Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Gas Transfer through Polar Sea Ice (GAPS) - Mechanisms of Turbulence Production in the Seasonal Ice Zone and its Control of Mixed Layer Ventilation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

High latitude ocean and sea ice surface fluxes of heat, momentum, fresh water and radiatively important gases such as carbon dioxide are critical to understanding polar, and thus global, climate processes. Field observations of these fluxes, and the physics and biogeochemistry that control them is hampered alternately by both the high winds and sea states typical of polar seas, and the complex potentially non-linear transport pathways between water, ice and air during conditions of active freezing and partial sea-ice cover.
This project will study, in a unique controlled laboratory facility, the relative contribution of the physical processes that regulate gas exchange through sea ice.

A seasonal evolution cycle of different sea-ice types found in the ice pack, namely 1) pancake ice, 2) complete ice cover, but with leads (openings), and 3) melted ice floes with a freshwater lens, will be simulated in a well controlled laboratory setting. Additionally, different turbulence regimes of wind, wave effects, convection and ice-water current shear at various levels of freezing will be studied in the CRREL sea ice pond facility (New Hampshire).


Potentially transformative nature of this research

The physics, and biogeochemistry of air-sea flux exchanges in heterogeneous and multi featured environment such as sea-ice is extremely challenging for any existing theory or computational approach. The observational approach that the investigators are using, introduction of chemically inert gases as deliberate tracers, has the ability to account for several different limiting steps encountered in gas exchange through sea ice. A multi-tracer (e.g. SF6, He, Ar, CO2...) mass balance approach has been used and refined by these investigators over the course of prior field campaigns at less challenging and more conventional air-sea boundaries. Preliminary results used to investigate the ice pond experimental approach have indicated that gas exchange through sea-ice does not scale with the amount of open water, negating what otherwise appeared to be a reasonable approximation. The resulting parameterization to be revealed by such studies may suggest redirection as to what really are the rate limiting steps of sea-ice flux transfers. These processes are important for accurate coupled Earth System Models of climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sea ice zone produces unique sources and sinks of turbulence that are not found in the open ocean.  At first pass, these mechanisms are (1) ice – water current shear, (2) mixing generated from ice floe wind-wave-current interaction and (3) buoyant convection.  These mechanisms (shown in the Sea-Ice Mixing image) are in addition to the most commonly cited mechanism that drives gas exchange – namely wind that produces waves at the water surface.  We ran two types of experiments in the wind tunnel: A. Varying Lead Conditions and B. Varying Ice Floe Conditions.

A.  Fractures in the sea-ice significantly affect the surface heat, moisture, and momentum fluxes in marginal ice zones. Narrow fractures in the pack ice caused by divergent motion are known as leads, whereas larger non-linear regions of open water of thin ice within the sea-ice pack are known as polynyas. These play the role of “ice factories” influencing the global ocean circulation and climate (e.g. Comiso and Gordon, 1998). During our GAPS experiments, sea-ice was cut to form leads of 5m and 15m.

B.  During GAPS, ice was grown in stages so as to cover various fraction of the water surface with chunks of ice known as floes. A video can be seen here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yrXycJLWGpU. The results indicate that at low flow rates, the percent ice cover has very little effect on the total gas transfer velocity.  In contrast, when the flow rate is higher, the rate of gas exchange is more sensitive to the percent ice cover.  This is in keeping with the expectation the wake around ice floes generates more turbulence  when the floes are not bunched together, but are free to move and interact with the mean current.

Addtionally, these ice floes showed evidence for increased mixing with increased ice fraction. Increased sea-ice fraction is thought to enhance turbulence and transfer velocities up to a certain point before reducing as the ice cover approaches 100%.  Results from our GAPS experiment support the theoretical relationship of gas transfer velocity to open water fraction (Brice et al., 2013). 

In summary:

1. Narrow leads and higher sea-ice floe coverage are associated with enhanced surface turbulence leading to a well-mixed ocean thermal skin layer, smaller ΔT, less horizontal variability, and enhanced air-sea exchanges for heat and gas.


2. Ice floe results support the form of the relation between transfer velocity and open water fraction proposed by Brice et al., (2013).
